newsitem.title: CHINA: Shenzhen B shares end up on Bengang rally.
newsitem.headline: Shenzhen B shares end up on Bengang rally.

text.p: Shenzhen's hard currency B share index closed slightly up on Friday, fuelled mainly by gains in market newcomer Bengang Steel Plates, analysts said.
The index edged up 1.25 points or 0.97 percent to 130.86 on turnover of HK$63 million against Thursday's HK$43 million.
The domestic A share index gained 1.96 point or 0.48 percent to 409.46 points on turnover of 3.8 billion yuan against 4.4 billion yuan in the previous session.
"The rise in B shares was mainly triggered by a rebound in Bengang," an analyst at China Guotai Securities said. "And the rebound was because the share has been oversold."
Bengang closed up HK$0.06 or 2.99 percent at HK$2.07 on volume of 2.3 million shares, placing it at the top of the B share active list.
Bengang, listed in early July at HK$2.38 per share, is the first B share listed in 1997 to remain below its offer price since its debut. Bengang listed in early July.
Analysts said some institutions intended pushing up Bengang to pave the way for upcoming new issues.
"Some investors are waiting for the listing of Lutai," an analyst at the Sun Hung Kai Investment Services Ltd said.

Lutai Textile Joint Stock Co Ltd launched an initial public offering of 80 million B shares from Thursday. The share issue, scheduled for completion by August 5, was priced at HK$1.93 per share for listing in Shenzhen.
Shenzhen Petrochemical was the best performer in the B share market, gaining HK$0.18 or 8.33 percent to HK$2.34 on volume of 3,000 shares.
Building materials producer Shenzhen Fangda Industrial Co, was supported by institutional demand on confidence in the company's 1997 interim profits, brokers said.
The issue advanced HK$0.73 or 6.47 percent to HK$12.01 on volume of 1.6 million shares, the day's third most actively traded counter.
Fangda contributed to the B share index rise, analysts said.
There were signs some foreinn investors were diverting their funds into B shares from the Hong Kong stock market, where profit-taking had emerged after recent strong rises, traders said.
Brokers said the A share market was still undergoing consolidation, adding A share trading lacked clear direction.
Yantian Harbour was the biggest A share gainer and the most actively traded issue, firming 0.96 yuan or 8.37 percent to 12.43 yuan on volume of 26.8 million shares.
Trading in Gintian Industry (Group) Co's A and B shares was suspended on Friday morning, when the Shenzhen-based conglomerate announced its 1997 interim results.
The company posted net profits 13.85 million yuan for the first half of 1997, down 54 percent from 29.84 milion yuan in the year-ago period.
Gintian, a conglomerate involved in real estate development, textile and foreign trade, was the first of the 49 Shenzhen-listed B share companies to release its 1997 interim earnings.
Trading in the company's shares resumed in the afternoon, with its B shares closing down HK$0.06 at HK$2.35 and A shares off 0.28 yuan at 7.77 yuan.
Domestic A share counter First Automobile Works Car Co Ltd reported a 59 percent surge in first half 1997 profits to 219.64 million yuan, from 138.37 million in the year-ago period.
Its last share trade was at 11.43 yuan, up 0.49 yuan in afternoon trading after a morning suspension for its results announcement.
